docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun

Tip

  • --precision=bfloat16 can give better performance
  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:

   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=reference \

  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.
  • --precision=bfloat16 can give better performance
  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.
  • --precision=float16 can help run on GPUs with less RAM / gives better performance
  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

Native

docs.title: Native Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Setup a virtual environment for Python
docs.text:
mlcr install,python-venv --name=mlperf
export MLC_SCRIPT_EXTRA_CMD="--adr.python.name=mlperf"

docs.title: # Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=rocm  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun

Tip

  • --precision=float16 can help run on GPUs with less RAM / gives better performance
  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev,_all-scenarios \
   --model=gptj-99.9 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.
  • --precision=bfloat16 can give better performance
  • --beam-size=1 Beam size of 4 is mandatory for a closed division submission but reducing the beam size can help in running the model on GPUs with lower device memory

docs.title: CUDA device
docs.text:
Please click here to see the minimum system requirements for running the benchmark

  • Device Memory: 80GB(fp32). 40GB(fp16)

  • Disk Space: 50GB

Docker

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

Tip

  • Default batch size is assigned based on GPU memory or the specified GPU. Please click more option for docker launch or run command to see how to specify the GPU name.

  • When run with --all_models=yes, all the benchmark models of NVIDIA implementation can be executed within the same container.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful
  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

docs.title: SingleStream
docs.text:

   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=SingleStream \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

docs.title: All Scenarios
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev,_all-scenarios \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge  \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

docs.title: Offline

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=gptj-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL

docs.title: # Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=rocm  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:

   --model=llama2-70b-99 \

   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

Docker

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

Tip

  • Default batch size is assigned based on GPU memory or the specified GPU. Please click more option for docker launch or run command to see how to specify the GPU name.

  • When run with --all_models=yes, all the benchmark models of NVIDIA implementation can be executed within the same container.

  • The dataset for NVIDIA's implementation of Llama2 is not publicly available. The user must fill this form and be verified as a MLCommons member to access the dataset.

  • PATH_TO_PICKE_FILE should be replaced with path to the downloaded pickle file.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 \
   --tp_size=2 \
   --nvidia_llama2_dataset_file_path=<PATH_TO_PICKLE_FILE> --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful
  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.

docs.text:
In the datacenter category, llama2-70b-99 has Offline, Server scenarios and all of the scenarios are mandatory for a closed division submission.

TensorRT

docs.title: TensorRT framework
docs.text: CUDA

docs.title: CUDA device
docs.text:
Please click here to see the minimum system requirements for running the benchmark

  • Device Memory: 2x80GB
Docker

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

Tip

  • Default batch size is assigned based on GPU memory or the specified GPU. Please click more option for docker launch or run command to see how to specify the GPU name.

  • When run with --all_models=yes, all the benchmark models of NVIDIA implementation can be executed within the same container.

  • The dataset for NVIDIA's implementation of Llama2 is not publicly available. The user must fill this form and be verified as a MLCommons member to access the dataset.

  • PATH_TO_PICKE_FILE should be replaced with path to the downloaded pickle file.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 \
   --tp_size=2 \
   --nvidia_llama2_dataset_file_path=<PATH_TO_PICKLE_FILE> --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.
OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful
  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.

LLAMA2-70B-99.9

edgedatacenter

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet  \
   --tp_size=<TP_SIZE> \
   --nvidia_llama2_dataset_file_path=<PATH_TO_PICKE_FILE>

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet  \
   --tp_size=<TP_SIZE> \
   --nvidia_llama2_dataset_file_path=<PATH_TO_PICKE_FILE>

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: # Run the Inference Server
docs.text:
mlcr run,vllm-server \
 --model=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --vllm_model_name=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --quiet

Tip

  • Host and Port number of the server can be configured through --host and --port options. Otherwise, server will run on the default host localhost and port 8000.

docs.text:

   --model=llama2-70b-99 \

   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 \
   --api_server=http://localhost:8000 \
   --vllm_model_name=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
   --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_repo.https://github.com/neuralmagic/inference,_branch.vllm --rerun

docs.text:
Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

Tip

  • It is advisable to use the commands in the Docker tab for CUDA. Run the below native command only if you are already on a CUDA setup with cuDNN and TensorRT installed.

docs.title: # Run the Inference Server
docs.text:
mlcr run,vllm-server \
 --model=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --vllm_model_name=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --quiet

Tip

  • Host and Port number of the server can be configured through --host and --port options. Otherwise, server will run on the default host localhost and port 8000.

docs.title: # Setup a virtual environment for Python
docs.text:
mlcr install,python-venv --name=mlperf
export MLC_SCRIPT_EXTRA_CMD="--adr.python.name=mlperf"

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: Native Environment
docs.text:
Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

Tip

  • It is advisable to use the commands in the Docker tab for CUDA. Run the below native command only if you are already on a CUDA setup with cuDNN and TensorRT installed.

docs.title: # Run the Inference Server
docs.text:
mlcr run,vllm-server \
 --model=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --vllm_model_name=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
 --quiet

Tip

  • Host and Port number of the server can be configured through --host and --port options. Otherwise, server will run on the default host localhost and port 8000.

docs.title: # Setup a virtual environment for Python
docs.text:
mlcr install,python-venv --name=mlperf
export MLC_SCRIPT_EXTRA_CMD="--adr.python.name=mlperf"

docs.title: # Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99 \
   --implementation=neuralmagic \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 \
   --api_server=http://localhost:8000 \
   --vllm_model_name=nm-testing/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf-FP8 \
   --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_repo.https://github.com/neuralmagic/inference,_branch.vllm --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

In the edge category, llama2-70b-99.9 has Offline, SingleStream scenarios and all of the scenarios are mandatory for a closed division submission.

pytorch

docs.title: pytorch framework
docs.text: cuda

docs.title: cuda device
docs.text: Native

docs.title: Native Environment
docs.text:
Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

Tip

  • It is advisable to use the commands in the Docker tab for CUDA. Run the below native command only if you are already on a CUDA setup with cuDNN and TensorRT installed.

You can reuse the same environment as described for llama2-70b-99.

docs.title: Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99.9 \
   --implementation=amd \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

   --quiet

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.0-dev \
   --model=llama2-70b-99.9 \
   --implementation=amd \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: Text Summarization using LLAMA3_1-405b
docs.text: MLCommons-Python

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

LLAMA3_1-405B-99

DockerNative

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

Tip

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_MODEL_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the model on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches.

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_DATASET_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the dataset on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches. 

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

Tip

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_MODEL_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the model on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches.

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_DATASET_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the dataset on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches. 

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

DockerNative

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text:
Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

You can reuse the same environment as described for llama3_1-405b-99.

docs.title: Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99.9 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: Offline
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99.9 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-405b-99.9 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cuda \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: Text Summarization using LLAMA3_1-8b
docs.text: MLCommons-Python

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

LLAMA3_1-8B

edgedatacenter

docs.title: Edge category
docs.text:
In the edge category, llama3_1-8b has Offline, SingleStream scenarios and all of the scenarios are mandatory for a closed division submission.

DockerNative

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

Tip

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_MODEL_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the model on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches.

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_DATASET_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the dataset on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches. 

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-8b \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=vllm \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

   --device=cpu \

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

Tip

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_MODEL_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the model on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches.

  • --env.MLC_MLPERF_DATASET_LLAMA3_DOWNLOAD_TO_HOST=yes option can be used to download the dataset on the host so that it can be reused across different container lanuches. 

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=llama3_1-8b \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=vllm \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

docs.text: MLCommons-Python

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

MIXTRAL-8X7B

edgedatacenter

docs.text:

docs.text:
Tip

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=mixtral-8x7b \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=mixtral-8x7b \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.title: Question and Answering using Bert Large for IndySCC 2024
Introduction
docs.text:
This guide is designed for the IndySCC 2024 to walk participants through running and optimizing the MLPerf Inference Benchmark using Bert Large across various software and hardware configurations. The goal is to maximize system throughput (measured in samples per second) without compromising accuracy.

For a valid MLPerf inference submission, two types of runs are required: a performance run and an accuracy run. In this competition, we focus on the Offline scenario, where throughput is the key metric—higher values are better. The official MLPerf inference benchmark for Bert Large requires processing a minimum of 10833 samples in both performance and accuracy modes using the Squad v1.1 dataset.

docs.title: Scoring
docs.text:
In the IndySCC 2024, your objective will be to run a reference (unoptimized) Python implementation of the MLPerf inference benchmark to complete a successful submission passing the submission checker. Only one of the available framework needs to be submitted.

Info

Both MLPerf and MLC automation are evolving projects. If you encounter issues or have questions, please submit them here

docs.title: Artifacts to submit to the SCC committee
docs.text:
All the needed files are automatically pushed to the GitHub repository if you manage to complete the given commands. No additional files need to be submitted.

MLCommons-Python

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

BERT-99

edge

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=bert-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=100 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

docs.title: Generate actual submission tree
docs.text:
mlcr generate,inference,submission \
   --clean \
   --run-checker \
   --tar=yes \
   --env.CM_TAR_OUTFILE=submission.tar.gz \
   --division=open \
   --category=edge \
   --env.CM_DETERMINE_MEMORY_CONFIGURATION=yes \
   --run_style=test \
   --quiet \
   --submitter=<Team Name>
  • Use --hw_name="My system name" to give a meaningful system name.

docs.title: Push Results to GitHub
docs.text:
Fork the mlperf-inference-results-scc24 branch of the repository URL at https://github.com/mlcommons/cm4mlperf-inference.

Run the following command after replacing --repo_url with your GitHub fork URL.

mlcr push,github,mlperf,inference,submission \
   --repo_url=https://github.com/<myfork>/cm4mlperf-inference \
   --repo_branch=mlperf-inference-results-scc24 \
   --commit_message="Results on system <HW Name>" \
   --quiet

Once uploaded give a Pull Request to the origin repository. Github action will be running there and once finished you can see your submitted results at https://docs.mlcommons.org/cm4mlperf-inference.

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

docs.text:

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=3d-unet-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Server\
   --server_target_qps=<SERVER_TARGET_QPS> \
   --execution_mode=valid \
   --device=cpu \
   --quiet

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

Tip

  • <SERVER_TARGET_QPS> must be determined manually. It is usually around 80% of the Offline QPS, but on some systems, it can drop below 50%. If a higher value is specified, the latency constraint will not be met, and the run will be considered invalid.

docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Setup a virtual environment for Python
docs.text:
mlcr install,python-venv --name=mlperf
export MLC_SCRIPT_EXTRA_CMD="--adr.python.name=mlperf"

docs.title: # Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=3d-unet-99 \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=rocm  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

Tip

  • Default batch size is assigned based on GPU memory or the specified GPU. Please click more option for docker launch or run command to see how to specify the GPU name.

  • When run with --all_models=yes, all the benchmark models of NVIDIA implementation can be executed within the same container.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=3d-unet-99 \
   --implementation=nvidia \
   --framework=tensorrt \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=50 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.
OfflineSingleStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful
  • --gpu_name=<Name of the GPU> : The GPUs with supported configs in MLC are orin, rtx_4090, rtx_a6000, rtx_6000_ada, l4, t4and a100. For other GPUs, default configuration as per the GPU memory will be used.

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL
OfflineServerAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

Tip

docs.title: # Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r4.0 \
   --model=3d-unet-99 \
   --implementation=intel \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=datacenter \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=10 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.

docs.title: Medical Imaging using 3d-unet (KiTS 2019 kidney tumor segmentation task)
Dataset
docs.text:
The benchmark implementation run command will automatically download the validation and calibration datasets and do the necessary preprocessing. In case you want to download only the datasets, you can use the below commands.

Unprocessed DatasetPreprocessed Dataset ValidationCalibration

3d-unet validation run uses the KiTS19 dataset performing KiTS 2019 kidney tumor segmentation task

  • --outdirname=<PATH_TO_DOWNLOAD_KITS19_DATASET> could be provided to download the dataset to a specific location.

docs.title: Get Validation Dataset
docs.text: mlcr get,dataset,kits19,_validation -j

docs.title: Get Calibration Dataset
docs.text: mlcr get,dataset,kits19,_calibration -j

docs.title: Get Preprocessed Validation Dataset
docs.text: mlcr get,dataset,kits19,preprocessed -j

docs.title: Model
docs.text:
The benchmark implementation run command will automatically download the required model and do the necessary conversions. In case you want to only download the official model, you can use the below commands.

Get the Official MLPerf 3d-unet Model

PytorchOnnxTensorflow
  • --outdirname=<PATH_TO_DOWNLOAD_3DUNET_MODEL> could be provided to download the model to a specific location.

docs.title: Pytorch
docs.text: mlcr get,ml-model,3d-unet,_pytorch -j

docs.title: Onnx
docs.text: mlcr get,ml-model,3d-unet,_onnx -j

docs.title: Tensorflow
docs.text: mlcr get,ml-model,3d-unet,_tensorflow -j

docs.title: Dataset
docs.text:
The benchmark implementation run command will automatically download the validation and calibration datasets and do the necessary preprocessing. In case you want to download only the datasets, you can use the below commands.

UnprocessedPreprocessed ValidationCalibration

Retinanet validation run uses the OpenImages v6 MLPerf validation dataset resized to 800x800 and consisting of 24,576 images.

Retinanet calibration dataset consist of 500 images selected from the OpenImages v6 dataset.

  • --outdirname=<PATH_TO_DOWNLOAD_OPENIMAGES_DATASET> could be provided to download the dataset to a specific location.

docs.title: Get Validation Dataset
docs.text: mlcr get,dataset,openimages,_validation -j

docs.title: Get OpenImages Calibration dataset
docs.text: mlcr get,dataset,openimages,_calibration -j

docs.title: Get Preprocessed OpenImages dataset
docs.text: get,dataset,object-detection,open-images,openimages,preprocessed,_validation -j

docs.title: MLPerf Reference Implementation in Python
docs.text:
Tip

  • MLCommons reference implementations are only meant to provide a rules compliant reference implementation for the submitters and in most cases are not best performing. If you want to benchmark any system, it is advisable to use the vendor MLPerf implementation for that system like Nvidia, Intel etc.

RETINANET

docs.title: Docker Environment
docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=retinanet \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=onnxruntime \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=100 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL

docs.text: Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

docs.title: # Docker Container Build and Performance Estimation for Offline Scenario
docs.text:
Tip

  • Compliance runs can be enabled by adding --compliance=yes.

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

  • _r4.1-dev could also be given instead of _r5.0-dev if you want to run the benchmark with the MLPerf version being 4.1.

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=retinanet \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=onnxruntime \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cuda  \
   --docker --quiet \
   --test_query_count=500 --rerun
The above command should get you to an interactive shell inside the docker container and do a quick test run for the Offline scenario. Once inside the docker container please do the below commands to do the accuracy + performance runs for each scenario.

Please click here to see more options for the docker launch

  • --docker_mlc_repo=<Custom MLC GitHub repo URL in username@repo format>: to use a custom fork of cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_mlc_repo_branch=<Custom MLC GitHub repo Branch>: to checkout a custom branch of the cloned cm4mlops repository inside the docker image

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

OfflineSingleStreamMultiStreamAll Scenarios

Please click here to see more options for the RUN command

  • Use --division=closed to do a closed division submission which includes compliance runs

  • Use --rerun to do a rerun even when a valid run exists

  • Use --compliance to do the compliance runs (only applicable for closed division) once the valid runs are successful

docs.title: Native Environment
docs.text:
Please refer to the installation page to install MLCFlow for running the automated benchmark commands.

Tip

  • It is advisable to use the commands in the Docker tab for CUDA. Run the below native command only if you are already on a CUDA setup with cuDNN and TensorRT installed.

docs.title: # Setup a virtual environment for Python
docs.text:
mlcr install,python-venv --name=mlperf
export MLC_SCRIPT_EXTRA_CMD="--adr.python.name=mlperf"

  • Number of threads could be adjusted using --threads=#, where # is the desired number of threads. This option works only if the implementation in use supports threading.

  • Batch size could be adjusted using --batch_size=#, where # is the desired batch size. This option works only if the implementation in use is supporting the given batch size.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=retinanet \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \

   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=cpu  \

  • --docker_cache=no: to not use docker cache during the image build

  • --docker_os=ubuntu: ubuntu and rhel are supported.
  • --docker_os_version=20.04: [20.04, 22.04] are supported for Ubuntu and [8, 9] for RHEL

  • Add --adr.mlperf-implementation.tags=_branch.master,_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the official MLPerf Inference implementation in a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.tags=_repo.<CUSTOM_INFERENCE_REPO_LINK> if you are modifying the model config accuracy script in the submission checker within a custom fork.

  • Add --adr.inference-src.version=custom if you are using the modified MLPerf Inference code or accuracy script on submission checker within a custom fork.

mlcr run-mlperf,inference,_find-performance,_full,_r5.1-dev \
   --model=retinanet \
   --implementation=reference \
   --framework=pytorch \
   --category=edge \
   --scenario=Offline \
   --execution_mode=test \
   --device=rocm  \
   --quiet \
   --test_query_count=100 --rerun
The above command should do a test run of Offline scenario and record the estimated offline_target_qps.
